commentBody:
This one kept blowing out the candles, it was so breezy.






cc: emu handler
This felt refreshingly straightforward for a Saturday.

Far too easy for a Saturday. 

BEANO and EBT crossing was unreasonable for a non-American.
Just like the clue for 57-Across, based on their Wordplay notes, the constructor too seems full of themselves. Agree with Sam below. Too easy for a Saturday.

YIKES!  Holy misdirection, Batman.  There were a lot of great clues today that had me going the wrong way.  My favorites were those for SYNONYM, TWISTERMAT, GEOCENTRIST, and MATRYOSHKADOLL.  Even after I got the answer on the last one, it took me a minute to get the spelling correctly - that O just didn’t look right, even though it was the only thing that made sense with cross.  

I also got bollixed up a bit because I confidently entered  bog instead of LOO, because my UK friends call it bog roll.

I spent a good couple minutes misdirecting myself: I saw “Best ever, informally” and got “_ _ A T” through crossings, and thought to myself “wow, that’s a fast turnaround for them to be cluing BRAT that way…”

I have to say for the Mini Crossword that frisbee discs are explicitly not used in the sport. Frisbee (company) is a disc maker (of very basic throwing discs) and its name is trademarked- hence the sport simply being called disc golf. There are a bunch of professional throwing disc manufacturing companies who specialize with using precision-made molds and plastics.
Fastest Saturday in a while, sub 10 minutes on a Saturday is once a month at best.

This morning I made a comment on Spelling Bee complaining that ZOOT wasn’t accepted. Glad to see it is in the crossword!

The EGO/GEO CENTRIST entry is just terrific!

A "proper Saturday" puzzle in my opinion.  Fairly hard although I confess I ended up completing it rather quickly.  The last thing for me was the hair brand which I'd never heard of.

The game gave me pause and maybe just a few moments of "panic" but was quite solvable and enjoyable in the end.  However I see from a quick glance down that others had an easier time than I did.

Different strokes of pen...

/Panicked emus still don't understand the K

Excellent clue for SYNONYM.  Of course I was initially fooled into putting an emphasis on the first syllable of ‘contracts’ instead of the second. A good misdirect. 

Great debut of MATRYOSHKA, and what a clever clue. I also like the playful mini-theme of TIKTOK DANCE, TWISTER MAT and PICKLEBALL. 

Luckily I already had BIGTOP, so didn’t fall into the egOCENTRIST trap. 

That was fun. Thanks, Spencer.
Saturday with no lookups! Not that it was an easy puzzle, just one free of excessive proper nouns.

I don’t know MATRYOSHKA so that annoyed me. Otherwise I would have been done in half the time. RACINOS is something I might have known but forgot. So it gave me trouble too. 

This is my birthday puzzle. I’m turning 50. The last few hours of my 40s. Honestly, I’ve been dreading it.

43 Down, about the camouflaged animal, is wrong. The animal’s pattern ward off reduce insect pests, not predators. Their predators’ vision isn’t sharp enough to even see the pattern from very far away, so it doesn’t affect their hunting.
A fun romp with a nice array of 9, 10, 11 letter entries.

Who ultraconfidently put chessboard in for 10D. 




Most emus wouldn’t

Any puzzle with MOSEY in it is okay by me. 
I had a hard time giving up Hyena for ZEBRA, but when I finally did things went much better.  
Lots of fresh entries in this with very friendly cluing.
Enjoyed a lot of the clues in this one but can someone explain 22A? Even after solving the puzzle and googling “SRO” I have no idea what the constructor is getting at.

Does this mean that we

will be getting Saturday's

puzzle on Monday?

Whew! Definitely Saturday.  I didn't know the word for the nesting dolls and needed Caitlin Lovinger's hints to finish Mr. Leach's wonderful puzzle. I enjoyed it, but my brain hurts. I started with "a narcissist" to get it to fit, but crosses nixed that one. The crosses were ok. The problem was finding a narcissistical word that started with a "g". Those two words were the only real worrisome and time consuming ones.  The rest took thought, but were all words I knew, so I had memory to give me the advantage. So today I learned two new words. Thank you Mr. Leach and NYTs crossword puzzle staff. 

Cheers from Texas. My thoughts are with family I have in Upper New York State and all those other's in Debbie's path.  Stay safe as much as you can. Turn around, don't drown.

CLUB FED, BIG TOP, ZOOT suit, RICO Nasty, ANITA Dunn,  MANIC PANIC, RACINOS, EBT, shofars, SRO, BEANO (what a ridiculous brand name!) - not knowing any of this stuff made the puzzle impossible to complete without lookups. I can't remember the last time a grid was so full of clues and answers completely alien to me. At least MATRYOSHKA was a gimme (after all, it used to be the most popular, Eastern European travel souvenir and novelty item).

Also, why are AMPS the answer to AC units and KILO to Grand opening?
I kept BOG roll as an answer for way too long!
I just could not see that I'd misspelled "problom" no matter how many times I went over the puzzle. I think it was a ME problem.

The Mini was just awful today. The clues are amateurish. Are you letting interns create those? The Mini has been going downhill for the past couple weeks. I just tried today’s and I can usually do them in about a minute. The clues were so awful I just quit after reading through them all.

Really enjoyed this one - some very clever clueing on the Down side (TWISTERMAT, GEOCENTRIST, SYNONYM!!, MOSEY, CLUBFED).

I was given a MATRYOSHKA with Gorbachev, Andropov, Brezhnev, Khrushchev, Stalin and a tiny Lenin years ago by a dear friend. But the South East corner required a leap of faith as it took me far too long to crack the clever clue and the end of the word is just the most fun sequence of letters!

I don’t think there can be objections to the use of BEANO and EBT when the puzzle also includes LOO roll! Anyway, this is the New York T crossword, so I’m just grateful I don’t need detailed, station by station knowledge of the subway system.

My only nit - by definition a BOLERO jacket is short and does NOT reach the waist! Off now for some Ravel with breakfast!
I don't get 24D - NES for "Switch's ancestor".
Did I wake up on a Wednesday? I swore it was the weekend today, but after starting the puzzle this morning, I actually had to double-check.

I will confess, I loved the non-PC, vegan-unfriendly PELTS.








I will now don my emu-feather bolero, and depart.
My first Saturday without any look ups!!! What a fun puzzle this was. And the clue for 57A was just delightful.

One of those puzzles where I gave up in despair 1/3 of the way through, picked it up a few hours later and whizzed through it.

Subconsciouses are amazing.

Big day for the oh-so-hip I-finished-in-three-minutes crowd, eh?  Talk about you're so full of yourself....

Speaking for the great unwashed, really appreciate the brilliant construction of this grid, Spencer.

Well... tough one for me, of course, and had to cheat a bit in a couple of places. More than a couple of completely unfamiliar answers, and some clues that I wasn't catching on to. That's all on me. 

For no explainable reason - wondered about a possible jokey clue/answer possibility:

"Good name for a bouncer?" RICKOSHEA

Nope - nothing like that has ever been in a puzzle. And of course I had a puzzle find today. I'll put that in a reply. 

..

Big and little pleasures in the box today.
•	MATRYOSHKA.  First pleasure when the meaning of [She’s so full of herself!]  hit me.  Second pleasure was remembering the Netflix series “Russian Doll”, which I adored.
•	NEMO over OMEN!  Abutting palindromes!
•	Enough footholds to flesh out answers that weren’t in my wheelhouse, yet sufficiently scattered that my brain’s work ethic was satisfied.  
•	BOLERO, evoking Ravel’s hypnotic piece.
•	Reading [Relatively nice prison, humorously] for CLUB FED, seeing “prison” as “person”, and thinking “I don’t get it!  Why would you call a nice person that?”  
•	An answer set pulsing with energy – words I haven’t come across in a long time (GEOCENTRIST, MATRYOSHKA, BOLERO), lovely colloquialisms (YOU BET I CAN, TEA, YOU PROBLEM), and zingy words (YIKES, ZOOT, PICKLEBALL).
•	The brilliant clue – [Contracts, for shrinks, e.g.] – that transformed SYNONYM from neutral to special.  The never-before-used clue for prolific answer ATM: [They don’t usually produce change].

A swag bag puzzle filled with lovely gifts.  Thank you, Spencer – what a sweet springboard to the day!

I never once stopped thinking that it said “Relatively nice person”.  After i resigned myself to “CLUBFED”, i was surprised to hear the happy music, because that is not a nice person.  

I do the crosswords to reassure myself that my brain is still working well, but that was not reassuring. 

Surely there are others who mis-read it too?

Oh well. Amam said there’d be days liek this.
Just for the record, Beano is not a gas "reliever", it *prevents* gas.

Fabulous. A tough nut to crack into, but such sweet meat when you do.  Great long entries at 13, 17, 54 and 57 A. I hadn’t come across 13A in my life as a punk, perhaps it didn’t cross the Pond. Food dye was our go to. Fine as long as it didn’t rain. Let’s face it, it rains a lot here, so many nights out ended with multicoloured streaks running down our faces.
Smiled at 37A. Sent a screenshot to my youngest who has been out and proud since he was 14. 
Great puzzle Spencer. More please.
Fun puzzle, but "screw the haters"?  Really?  Was that necessary?
It will never feel okay to me to use “leisurely” as an adjective. The rule is noun ly=adjective and adjective ly=adverb.
I didn't remember the term "Matryosshka" dolls, but got a set in Moscow in the 70's that have Soviet leaders stuffed inside each other. Pretty funny.

Absolutely fell to the ground laughing at the "She's so full of herself!" clue. I would have loved if you put a question mark next to the clue, would've been MUCH easier to figure out! Made me and my boyfriend's Saturday.
This one just flew by for me. Spencer of a year ago and I are on the same page today! Only stumble was holding onto BOG for 39D for way too long.

Cute to see NEMO directly atop its semordnilap OMEN.

Some nice entries in this grid: MATRYOSHKA, GEOCENTRIST, MICROSCOPE, SYNONYM.

Had no idea why a relatively nice *person* would be a CLUBFED, humorously or otherwise. Made a lot more sense after rereading the clue!

Clever clues included "She's so full of herself!" for MATRYOSHKA, "Contracts for shrinks, e.g." for SYNONYM" and "To whom one might say `Not everything revolves around you!'" for GEOCENTRIST. On the other hand, the long clue for PICKLEBALL seemed clunky, and I might reserve "ferocious" for hurricane-force winds. 

Despite having never heard on MANICPANIC, I managed to solve this one unaided, in about half-an-hour. Seemed like a nice Saurday puzzle to me.
That was so good! I really loved this one. Plenty of great and even funny fill. I’m looking forward to more like this

"Won't anyone help me find my sheep?"
"That sounds like a ewe problem."

("It sheer is!")
No muss, no fuss, very few throwaways.  Thanks.
ashamed of how quickly i got MANIC PANIC as a former emo teen

“Plus, bonus points for the use of the word ‘mosey’…”
— Oz

Buffyphiles unite

This puzzle here is a real good time, but not a real long time.

(I wonder if that will still be the case when people do it “from tape” in the archives in years to come?)

Such a fun fill today! Absolutely flew by, definitely a Saturday PB. Lively clueing and fill. As a younger solver I appreciated a few of the more contemporary answers - they felt like a rare Saturday treat!

About a zillion years ago--well, in the mid-70's, anyway--I was  in Heidelburg looking for children's gifts, and I was pleased to find *Russische Holzpuppen* in a lovely shop.  That is name enough for me, having seen multiple mangled spellings through the years.     (Yes, I googled after I finished the puzzle, and this was one of them, which was correct according to the crossiings.)  The one I kept for myself did not survive life with our children, but I do still have the tiniest wee one in my type-setter's display case of small souvenirs.  If you move a lot IN REAL LIFE (TSK) small things last longest.

RACINOS, eh?  YIKES.  So many ways to lose one's money.

It was kinda fun seeing SNOOP Dogg and some Muppets in scenes from Paris...I started wondering if Dogg was a coach or something. 

Sorry, Spencer Leach, no MOL PELT to display on your trophy wall this time, despite all the new words and unknown persons and movements.

I had a wide variety of four letter words ready for “exclamation of exasperation”, several starting with C.  But CMON wasn’t one of them.

Also wasted a long time trying to make ING fit in 33D, as in “running dog.”

Having been raised in Idaho, I know the potato has a long and illustrious history, and was “domesticated” sometime before 5000 BCE. 

I also know the INCA, as an empire, existed in the 15th and 16th centuries CE. 

I’m pretty sure there were civilizations in the region of what is now southern Peru that were cultivating potatoes in the six, or so, millennia before the INCA.

David and MB in an earlier post cleared up 24D NES which I didn't understand either. Nintendo Entertainment System. Thanks.

I also didn't get EBT for 44A. It's Electronic Benefit Transfer which come to think of it I've seen in previous puzzles. Had to Google that.

Some folks didn't like the clue for 8D [Grand opening?] and I agree, it's a bit of a stretch. Grand is a noun meaning 1,000 and KILO also refers to 1,000, yes, but grand is a noun and KILO in this sense is a combining form (as the MW dictionary has it), so the one is not strictly a SYNONYM of the other. 

People who make Ultraconfident (is that even a word?) affirmations are so often proved ultrawrong and so it was with me when I wrote in absolutely for 54A. Well, it fit. 

I enjoyed the puzzle overall, liked 27D YOU PROBLEM which is new to me but probably something I will say in the future. I imagine it comes from somewhere, anyone know?
This is a puzzle that makes greeting a rainy Saturday joyous.  Brain twisting, imaginative, educational, youthful!
Such great fun today! Thanks Spencer.
Not particularly difficult for a Saturday but I enjoyed the fill
Having a mental blockage with 35D, SYNONYM. Everyone is loving this answer, but I can't seem to get the connection! Please explain?
A new Saturday best at 19:35! Easy for a Sunday but very fun, thank you.

Apropos 39d: that great 60s R&B singer Rawls was never as successful or taken as seriously in Britain as were his contemporaries like Sam Cooke, Otis Redding or Curtis Mayfield. You do have to wonder why…

Was felling pretty good about myself until I had to throw in the towel at MATRYOSHKA (so that's what those things are called!)  

SYNONYM for [Contracts for shrinks, e.g.] the favorite.  Well done.
OMG, just read Deb’s column. Shows how carefully I read the clues — couldn’t for the life of me figure out why CLUBFED fit for “relatively nice PERSON” haha.

I'll start the thread.   No spoilers until we reach the "View All Replies" bar. 


Strands #160
“Not just for poking”
🔵🔵🟡🔵
🔵🔵🔵


Probably the simplest Spangram I've seen.  Should have gotten it sooner.
i was sure AC units were BTUS, which led to TANIC PANIC...
MATRYOSHKA and TIK TOK DANCE were particular favorites, but nice overall.  Thanks, Spencer.
MATRYOSHKA!!!!  Worth the price of admission folks.
26D To whom one might say "Not everything revolves around you!" ... DONALDTRUMP fit perfectly
Nice, easier than usual (for me), and altogether delightful! Well done! MATRYOSHKA, and OPENLY GAY were masterfully clued.

I’m not really finding a source that supports ‘casino’ being a portmanteau. Seems like it’s just an Italian word meaning literally “little house”  but was colloquially used to refer to a little house of gambling.

Curious solve. Did not get a single long answer--across or down--on the first pass, but, though I did not rush, was done in less than half my average. So I came here to see what other folks' experiences were. Was the puzzle easy for a Saturday?Were the crosses just in my wheelhouse? Did my extra sleep last night make me smarter?  

The comments seem to suggest that other solvers' experiences were quite a mix. For me, the mix was within this single puzzle. Some really crunchy clues with surprising answers, but every sweep through the hints yielded more ahas, resulting in a smooth solve time. Learned a few new things, too.
Amazed I was able to spell MATRYOSHKA right on the first try! I found this puzzle way easier and more approachable than most Saturdays and I loved it.

Dang. 

I guess I am the only one who does not know the word for the Russian nesting dolls.

That had me going around in circles for quite a long time.

I would complain that it is a word that hardly anybody knows, but after reading the comments, I see that's not true.

Plus I exercised all of my available masochism on the puzzle.

Nice! I like the clue for 57A but for a while I had filled in WHATA...figuring that ....KA  had to be a Yiddish insult I just hadn't heard of. And so 35D had to end in LAW....some kind of special arrangement you make with your therapist?
Proud of my nine day streak! Which includes two Saturdays! Almost afraid to look at the next puzzle... Thanks for a fun puzzle.

Working with incarcerated people as I do, I always cringe when words and clues related to our inhumane criminal justice system pop up here, especially when couched in humor, but this one--focused as it was on our least terrible prisons--didn't strike me as too thoughtless. 

And any puzzle with MANICPANIC, OPENLYGAY, and the devilishly clever clues for 26D and 35D (which it took me way too long to understand) couldn't be *bad*--even if it did force me to spell MATRYOSHKA. 

So thank you, Spencer Leach & eds., for a perfectly fun Saturday solve. S**** the haters, indeed!

My own favorite clue was [Contracts for shrinks, e.g.] Diabolical! Genius! I got MATRYOSHKA after I had about half the crosses--I would not have spelled it correctly without them!  I had BEEF instead of TIFF for a bit but otherwise it wasn't so much misdirections as tricky clues that slowed me down.  Finished it well below my average Saturday--Thanks to Mr. Leach for a fun puzzle!
Meh. 2.5 stars.
Cleverly clued! I really enjoyed this one. I must have had my thinking cap on because I finished in 15 minutes without using the wordplay article for hints, super rare for a Saturday for me!

TIL that there is a "Y" in the middle of what I thought was spelled "matrushka".  
I also ultraconfidently entered BOG for 39D, and BURST worked OK for 39A (this was early in the solve), but really needed my ZOOT suit for the cross. 
Live and learn!

The more relatively nice persons I see in the comments here today, the more I want to ask the constructor and/or editors: 

Was the wording of that clue at 15D intentional misdirection along the lines we have seen pan out, or just a happy accident (perhaps discovered in beta-testing, or focus groups, or whatever goes on pre-publishing)? My respect for the genius minds behind these puzzles makes me suspect the former, but staring at the clue I kinda sense the other.

Cmon, throw us an answer bone here - or at least a club sandwich.
Annyoed at the mini. 9As answer is trademarked for a specific toy/type of Disc and does not count as an answer the clue.

ZOOT and ZEBRA were my first two fills. 
I’m only an occasional Saturday solver, so anytime I finish one without resorting to AutoCheck, and under average I know it’s going to be pilloried for being too easy. And some answers were clued to an early week level.
I did this while half watching the 10 meter diving, now that’s hard!
Loved Grand Opening, and She’s so full of herself.
Overall quite fun and nicely done.

SW corner did me in. I couldn't settle on BEANO, didn't get NEMO and EBT. Had REALLIFE instead of REALTIME.  I was feeling a bit old for parts of this. Also, am I supposed to know the name of every rapper that ever existed?

I kept setting aside and coming back to this fun puzzle, and every time I came back, I made a bit of progress. The clue for MATRYOSHKA was great, and there were many others I enjoyed. We bought a few Matryoshka dolls when visiting the USSR way back in 1983. It was an interesting trip, a bit scary at times, but memorable. 
Thanks for the challenge and the fun, Spencer Leach.

Caitlin Lovinger's first line of the Wordplay column is SO ON POINT: 

"Spencer Leach has a gift for tweaking things that might look irritating at first into amusements — every corner of this puzzle had a clue or entry that could have made me bristle, until I parsed it completely, got the wink and had to smile."

What fun for a Saturday!! 37A, 57A, and 35D were just brilliant clues--and really made me smile.

Hah! That'll be the day, when I start on a Friday or Saturday puzzle with any kind of ultraconfident affirmation, or anything that remotely resembles YOU BET I CAN.
It's more like MANIC PANIC, which slowly gives way to surprise, and then uncontained bliss, with every entry I get right.  

I had to get the name of the nested dolls, MATRYOSHKA, from the crosses, despite having received them as a present in 1985. 
A journalist friend brought them back from a trip to Moscow, purchased at GUM Department Stores. 
"Please note the wrapping paper," he said, "It's part of the gift, since you're a Design student."
All I saw was rough butcher paper, with a dingy off-white background, and a blurry pattern in dull red and dull green.
"That's their gift wrap," he added, with a sly smile on his face. 
"A taste of the Soviet Union's graphic arts at its finest."
I kept that gift wrap for the longest time, as if it were some kind of archeological treasure – which, well, in the design world, it was. 

This recollection, along with that of all the ROFL occasions of playing TWISTER, threw some additional spice into an already spicy puzzle, filled with smart misdirects, and so fulfilling to solve.

Thank you, Mr. Leach! Go ahead and be proud. You've earned it!
Well done! I don't think I've ever been so initially angry at a puzzle that, in the end, I wound up respecting so much.

Fun puzzle, just chewy enough. Thanks, Spencer.

But, what the heck? 33D was a bugaboo for me.
I ambival, I diffid, I diverg.
I prud but I won't viol.
Nothing evids or incids.
(Some might insol and say the constructor indols. But I retic.)
Please, fellow solvers, I urg, make it coher and cog.
I can't think of any verbs to which you simply add ENT to make an adjective.

I'll probably think of some once I hit submit.

Today I learned that matryoshka means "little mother."  That reminded me of a cartoon where a female-figured matryoshka was at a movie theater booth asking for one adult ticket. The rest is up to your imagination.

Oh! A remarkable late puzzle find. It's late here so I'll probably repost this tomorrow. Anyway - A Sunday from May 19, 1991 by Ralph G. Beaman with the title: "DITTO." The puzzle had 7 squares that were a rebus of the " sign. Each of them implied a repeat of one string of letters (mostly one word but in two cases two words) leading into them, both across and down. Some example answers: AMERICA"GODSHED ITSAMADMAD"WORLD OVERTHERE"SENDTHEWORD HOMEAGAINHURRAH" ITISAFAR"BETTER And some down crossings: MAHI" HAIL" NEWYORK" HIP" Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=5/19/1991&g=40&d=A ..

I guess, you do not need my voice, NYT? As an introvert, even posting an anonymous comment is a big move. And when it never appears, crushing! But I'll get over it...timidly adding a Happy Weekend to you all...oh, and the puzzle? Tough, for me, but a challenge happily accepted, and completed, with one teensy Google...cheers!

A really fabulous puzzle! So, so many lovely clues and the first time I completed a Saturday puzzle on my own, unaided, and actually at a reasonable speed for a Thursday, let alone a Saturday! TIKTOKDANCE had a great clue, with plenty of others as well. I can't really criticise anything here, there didn't seem to be much crosswordese to me.

Thank you, Spencer! This one will be especially memorable to me!
Well done Spencer! This puzzle was fantastically crafted. 29A had me thinking about Trader Joe's, but maybe that was just the peanut butter cups I was munching on...

Really really nice one 

Had CLUBMED forever which was really messing me up

I’m very late, but I liked this one as much as everyone else. Tough, fair, and fun. Words like MATRYOSHKA add a lot by violating assumptions we rely on about which letter combinations are expected in English and which are rare.

I finished last night before bed and woke up this morning still thinking about it and  chuckling at my generational connection to both Manic Panic (used “Fire Red” my freshman year of college” and “Tik Tok Dance,” both of which I got without bristling. Fun puzzle — and I’ll definitely be hitting Chelsea Hardware next time I’m in NYC to check out that matryoshka collection!
Wow, I did it. f I can make it here, I can make it anywhere!!! I see no reason my current 12 day streak with no look-ups shouldn't stretch on to infinity.
Suffix that turns verb into an adjective. Shouldn’t that read into a noun?

Well yesterday I only got TELEX because I am reading a reporter’s family’s autobiography and today I only got MANIC PANIC because I was thinking of turning my hair electric blue. It turns out that it’s too much bleaching but…hey! I love that rhyme. I can’t believe this is a whole year-old puzzle. Wow, congratulations.

@Steve L Brand names can be anything, as can abbreviations. BrANO BiANO, BlANO BoANO BwANO,  for that matter, BzANO, or pretty much anything else is possible when we have Yandex, Aetna, Aflac, and Zygna come up, often crossing with abbreviations for US Universities...

Lisa,

Yes, brand names 
and abbreviations 
can be anything, 
but you're overlooking 
Steve's point about 
inferring BEAN- 
from [Gas relief...].



"Mongo like beans."

 





No sure about emus

@Marianne 

From the constructor's note:

"started out with my clue/answer pair for GEOCENTRIST (did anyone try egocentrist?), and the hits never stopped! Clues like [She's so full of herself!]"

Perhaps his notes were delivered with his tongue firmly planted in his cheek?
@Marianne Maybe this is where egocentric comes in handy (wink wink).

@Marshall Walthew 

I first learned the word MATRYOSHKA around 1990, when I saw a set of dolls that had Stalin enclosing Khrushchev enclosing Brehznev enclosing Gorbachev enclosing Yeltsin. (I guess Andropov and Chernenko didn’t count.)

@Eric Hougland

What, no Lenin either? In any event, that’s a clever set of dolls.
@Chris Today’s Mini clues and puzzle were just awful IMO…
@Chris That's gonna be hard to fit in the grid...

@Chris

I know right? Innova and Dynamic didn’t work. Though I do remember way back in the early 90s there were people who would use Ultimate Frisbees on the disc golf courses we used to play on so I guess it works. Amatuers!

@Ann 

My computer Scrabble game won’t accept ZOOT, either. In its defense, neither of the dictionaries I use list ZOOT as an entry separate from ZOOT suit.

@Dan

As one on the cusp of leaving the 50s and seriously dreading the big 60,  I  know how you feel.   However looking back, 50s was  probably one of my best decades.       10 years from now I hope to have a similar epiphany.
@Nom De Plume  Thanks for replying. Ok I’ll work on being more positive! I’m in Mexico City for the first time. Maybe seeing the ancient pyramids will make me feel less old! ❤️

@Nathan   What if the hyenas' current camouflage evolved eons ago to protect them from previous predators with good vision?  What we are looking at now might be just the remnants of an evolutionary change that was so successful, it is no longer needed.
@HEK Meant to say "zebra."  Hyena had been my initial thought for that clue, so it was still on my mind.
Nathan, Rather than "wrong," how about "not considered the most likely" reason? https://www.bbc.com/future/article/20191031-the-truth-behind-why-zebras-have-stripes striped emus

@Darren B 

Standing Room Only – for 
shows that sell out of seats.

It's a good one to commit to memory, as it often pops up in puzzles.

Hope this helps.
@Darren B Standing Room Only

@Andrzej AC is alternating current here, amps is a unit of measure for electrical current. 

A grand is also colloquial for 1,000, just like kilo.

@Wilson 

Thanks, I get the kilo/grand thing now, in a way - in a way because I still don't understand how the clue works. "Opening" in clues usually means the answer will be the prefix of the word in the clue. So I would expect the answer to "Grand opening?" to be something along the lines of MGM (well, not today, because that's not four letters, but you see what I mean). How is KILO an opening to grand?
@Edward I did too! I was baffled by what on earth a ZOgT suit was for ages...

@Edward 
Would have been completely appropriate as it’s used almost as often as LOO, though I think a little class snobbishness separates the choice of which is generally used. I knew it was ZOOT therefore the choice was made for me.

@Helen Wright 
Yet if one tries to use ZOOT for many word games, it's not accepted....

@KC 
I found it refreshing that instead of just entering the across clues on autopilot I actually had to use the crosses to solve it just like a regular puzzle.

@KC 

Funny, I think I did the exact same Mini as you did, and I thought it played like any other Mini.

Steve,

I share your amazement at how the “subconscious” works - your amazement, and that of many who post here from time to time about the value of “giving it a rest” to solve tricky puzzles. I often think about such comments. Something about today - the clues in this puzzle, my mood? - means here is where I’m going to reply.

Like any good geo- or egocentrist, we are each inescapeably in thrall of our self-consciousness. I am guessing that most people are like me: I imagine I “know what I’m doing” and take a little pride in my thinking skills when I think about a clue and then think of the answer. But actually, I am clueless about how thinking works. Though I have no idea how I “come up with” the correct answers even when I am consciously thinking of them (or, for that matter how I fail to when thinking just as hard), it is only occasionally that I become “aware” of this ineffable experience of suddenly receiving (or not) conscious grasp of a thought or idea or fact. The answers simply arrive in a kind of cognitive dumb-waiter, and are handed to me. The frustration is that sometimes the dumb-waiter is on a different schedule than “I” am.

Minds amaze me - conscious, subconscious, and everything in between.

@JohnWM 

Cognitive dumb-waiter!
I love that.




Emu, a cognitive dumb wader.

@Rob Richards 
Your confusion is because the answer to that clue is not "casino," which is not, as you indicate, a portmanteau.  The answer is "racino," which is place combining a race track where bets are made and a casino where people gamble.  It's "race" combined with "casino" equals "racino."

@Dave 
I really don’t get this criticism. Chris from Maryland brought this up last night and others have concurred.  I get it that there are a number of brands of discs which are predominantly used in the sport and sponsor professional disc golfers. But many of us think of the sport as Frisbee-golf and that term can be found in M-W.  And remember The Summer of George and “Frolf” (Frisbee-golf for Costanza). The term has been used at least nine times before in the NYT crosswords. Two other Wham-O products, Hula Hoop and Slip ‘n Slide, have also appeared. IMHO, it’s like complaining that “Oreos” should be abandoned for “sandwich cookies”.

I don’t know if it was easy or I was just absolutely on the same wavelength as the constructor. Can’t remember so many Saturday answers that fell so quickly. PICKLEBALL was a gimme. GALEFORCE, RACINOS, OPENLYGAY, TWISTERMAT all popped in effortlessly. Heck when I saw _____ suit first thing that came to mind was ZOOT even before I saw ZEBRA, how weird is that? Only corner that gave me a little pause was the SE but loved the MATRYOSHKA clue, my grandmother had them. I don’t know if everyone will find it so easy, I just think it’s one of those days when everything clicked for me. In any case fun and well-constructed.

Thanks, Mr. Leach, for making me feel like I know more than I do. I zipped through your colorful grid without much delay, almost matching my time on yesterday’s puzzle.

I really enjoyed your clues for 57A MATRYOSHKA and 10D TWISTER MAT.

Ironically, OPENLY GAY was one of the last things I filled in. This weekend sees Austin’s Pride Parade, which I have marched in a few times. (Why August? Because June in Central Texas is too hot!)

Thanks for the fun.

Rich in Atlanta,

Very recently, I did the puzzle from Sunday, September 27, 2015 by Tom McCoy - the puzzle was titled “Mark My Words”. 

That puzzle also involved the use of a double quotation mark as the sole character in a number of squares. Even now in 2024 the app-based keyboard provided in the NYT Games app for my iPad does not include such a double quotation mark. As such, the puzzle was not able to be completed by me in my medium of choice (a fact that was indicated in the puzzle information comments - but I had (wrongly) imagined maybe things had been updated in the past 8 years). 

I saw some of the online comments from enraged solvers in 2015, when apparently iPad users were similarly left powerless. 

I presume in 1991, such social unrest was unheard of. Any insights or quotations from you or others on what went down in the “20th century”?

An interesting coincidence: the answer to #54 ("Ultraconfident affirmation") also appears in today's Los Angeles Times Daily Crossword.

Once again, I didn't find it as easy as many commenters but also, like yesterday, for about 3/4 of it, I thought I'd have a personal best. It was the same little section as yesterday that held me up.... the NE.

When I finished everything else and came back, I reluctantly stripped big brother out of 11D, which turned out to be MICROSCOPE, but TWISTER MAT (which was awesome btw) gave me a dickens of a time. I didn't know SRO or RICO and kept feeling like it should be twitter xxx (ban?) and though I kept ripping it out, my mind was a bit fixated on it -- even after stepping away and coming back a couple times. 

It came together but I don't count it as a clean win for me because I eventually looked up RICO and also confirmed that my ATMS was correct. I was mildly worried because it read "they don't usually..." and I didn't think they ever did. 

Anyhow, all good!!  Very fun one! 

Loads of fun misdirects and other fun clues!  My nemesis of TWISTER MAT probably being my favorite - ha - along with MATROYSHKA doll. I came back from Siberia back in 2000 with a half a suitcase full of them. Still proudly displayed!  Also love SYNONYM! 

Also liked that YIKES crossed PELTS because that about sums it up for me!
